text.p: These are the highlights of the main Sao Paulo and Rio de Janeiro newspapers this morning.
-- SAO PAULO REFINANCES 50 BLN REAIS IN DEBT, LOSES BANESPA

With a 50.4 billion reais debt refinancing deal, the Brazilian federal government has found a solution for troubled Sao Paulo state bank Banespa. It also imposed severe fiscal adjustments to be carried out by the Sao Paulo state government.
-- CMN RESTRICTS USE OF CREDIT CARDS

The performance of Brazil's external accounts led the government to submit to the National Monetary Council (CMN) new measures to tame a growing trade deficit. The CMN on Thursday restricted credit card use abroad by making consumers pay for entire purchases all at once on their first bill.
-- GDP FALLS IN THE FIRST QUARTER
Data from the National Statistics Institute (IBGE) reveal that Brazil's gross domestic product (GDP) fell 0.56 percent in the first quarter of this year compared with the last quarter of 1996.

President Fernando Henrique Cardoso said "Brazilian society wants an end to the climate of mayhem," which results from a "premeditated wave of violence and anarchy". Cardoso was referring to recent violent demonstrations against the government and invasions of landless and homeless people in public buildings.
-- MOTTA NO LONGER CARDOSO'S POLITICAL COORDINATOR
President Fernando Henrique Cardoso has invited Deputy Luis Eduardo Magalhaes, former Lower House president, to replace Communications Minister Sergio Motta as the government's political coordinator.
In 16 hours, former soldier Genildo Ferreira de Franca, 25 years-old, killed 15 people in the remote northeastern city of Sao Goncalo do Amarante in Rio Grande do Norte state.
-- Reuters has not verified these stories and cannot vouch for their accuracy.
